Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Symbiosis and Repercussions of Extreme Ecological Specificity
Award.AbstractNarration:
The non-photosynthetic plant Pterospora andromedea relies on an obligate relationship with a fungus in the genus Rhizopogon to obtain carbon and energy. This fungus in turn relies on an obligate association with conifer trees to obtain its carbon and energy. Such complex tripartite symbioses have been little studied. However, under conditions of human disturbance or climate change, extreme dependence on highly specific associations within the relationships may lead to population decline. Indeed, populations of Pterospora are in steep decline in eastern North America, but appear to be secure in the west. The proposed research will investigate the historic association, co-migration and genetic structure in Pterospora/Rhizopogon pairs from across North America. The central hypothesis is that health and vigor of this relationship will be highest in the center of its geographic range (e.g. Pacific Northwest) and that populations that exist outside of this optimal center, including those that are disjunct or at range margins (New England), will exhibit lower relative abundance and higher genetic differentiation, possibly due to increased effects of genetic drift and reduced gene flow. This investigation will elucidate historic patterns and variation in ecological specificity in this complex plant-fungal symbiosis and determine factors that explain contemporary patterns of population genetic structure of symbionts at the community level.

This is a collaborative project that involves the synergistic melding of complementary expertise between two research teams, one from a small, liberal arts college (Centre College) and the other at a research intensive University (U of Wyoming). This collaboration will support research training and mentoring of a postdoctoral scholar, and several graduate students. Further, this research will fundamentally enhance the liberal arts learning environment at a primarily rural undergraduate institution by providing a dynamic research opportunity to stimulate the scientific development of undergraduate students and a meaningful mentorship opportunity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological diversity, as we know it today, stands as a testament to the dynamism of evolutionary processes acting within populations and to the long-term relationships established among populations of species composing natural communities. However, to date, it is unclear how highly specialized interactions among species influence the evolutionary trajectories of associated lineages over time. Our research aims to address this fundamental gap in our understanding of co-evolving lineages by utilizing a highly specialized relationship between the nongreen plant, Pterospora andromedea (woodland pinedrops) and the soil fungus Rhizopogon, from which the plant essentially derives all of its necessary nutrition.   Our collaborative team from the University of Wyoming and Centre College, composed of undergraduate researchers, graduate students, a postdoctoral fellow, and two principle investigators, set out to assess the evolutionary patterns inherent to this relationship using multiple molecular techniques to study plant and fungal tissue samples collected from contemporary populations across the geographic range of Pterospora. Pterospora is known to grow in two discrete regions of continental North America with rare, eastern populations extending from the upper New England States into Ontario and Quebec, Canada. There is a marked absence of Pterospora populations throughout the tall grass prairie region of central North America but populations become abundant in the western United States extending along the Rocky and Sierra Nevada Mountain Ranges down into the Sierra Madres in western Mexico and throughout the Pacific Northwest into Canada. Interestingly, when molecular markers were used to analyze Rhizopogon in direct association with Pterospora populations within these two disjunct regions, a new fungal species not yet known to science, Rhizopogon kretzerae, was discovered in the eastern region but not in the west.  Furthermore, through the use of modern genetic analyses this new species was shown to be a close relative of other Rhizopogon species known to associate with Pterospora populations in eastern and western North America.  Our collaborative team has continued to develop molecular genetic tools that will give both broad- and fine-scale insights into the evolutionary histories of this plant, these fungal lineages, and the historic patterns of their movement across the North American landscape.  Ultimately, it is our goal to analyze these prevailing patterns to ascertain factors responsible for the maintenance and perpetuation of the symbiosis between Pterospora and its Rhizopogon fungal associates.  Once we have obtained a better understanding of evolutionary patterns that emerge from our chosen study system, we sincerely hope our findings will be applied to better understand other highly specialized ecological relationships.  The overall goal of our work is to enhance humanity’s grasp on how interactions among species within the natural world came to be and how we might work to maintain the integrity of our global biodiversity for countless future generations.
